    Compile model and fit to data

    fm_fit_model.Rd

    Compile model and fit to data

    fm_fit_model(
  fm_data_inputs,
  SE = 1,
  data_source = 1,
  data_obs = 2,
  samp_process = 0,
  b_constraint = 2,
  const_spphab = 1,
  cov_samp_process = 0,
  biomass_temporal = 1,
  sampling_temporal = 0,
  anisotropy = 0,
  lf_link = 0,
  ref_data = "com",
  EM = "est_b",
  month_ref = 1,
  compute_sd = FALSE
)

    Arguments

    fm_data_inputs

    list Named list obtained from `fm_load_data()`

    SE

    integer run ADREPORT - 0: no, 1: yes

    data_source

    integer 1: integrated model (scientific + commercial data), 2: scientific model, 3: commercial model

    data_obs

    integer observation model for biomass - 1: zero_inflated gamma, 2: zero-inflated lognormal, 3: lognormal

    samp_process

    integer Sampling process - 0: no sampling process, 1: inhomogeneous Poisson point process

    b_constraint

    integer put constraint on b parameters - 1: b are positive, 2: no constraints

    const_spphab

    integer Species-habitat relationship - 1: constant in time

    cov_samp_process

    integer covariate in the sampling process - 0: none, 1: covariate in the samplign process

    biomass_temporal

    integer Account for temporal correlation in biomass - 0: no, 1: AR1

    sampling_temporal

    integer Account for temporal correlation in sampling process - 0: no, 1: AR1

    anisotropy

    integer Account for anisotropy

    lf_link

    integer link function of the latent field - 0: log (biomass data), 1: logit (presence absence data)

    ref_data

    character reference data - "com": commercial (default) or "sci": scientific

    EM

    character "est_b": b is estimated, "fix_b": b is fixed

    month_ref

    integer reference month (default is 1 for January)

    compute_sd

    logical compute SD report (time-consumming)

    Value

    list A named list of all necessary outputs for generating graphs (step 3)

    Contents

    Developed by Baptiste Alglave, Sebastien Rochette, Swann Floc’hlay.
